Award.AwardTitle: Large systems with repulsive interactions in statistical mechanics, condensed matter physics and PDE
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nature is governed by interaction forces between particles, such as the electrostatic and gravitational forces. Some of these forces are attractive, some are repulsive. For instance, the formation of crystals, which are periodic arrangements of atoms, can be very roughly explained via repulsive forces coupled with a binding force. This project takes a mathematical and general view on a class of such phenomena: given a system of N points (or particles) with a specific repulsive interaction (typically the Coulomb repulsive force encountered in electrostatics, or other interactions which are in inverse power of the distance between two points), together with a confining force, one would like to describe the typical macroscopic and microscopic behavior of the system as the number of points N gets very large, and possible thermal effects are included (temperature being expected to add disorder to the system). The research of the PI is concretely related to important physics models: the arrangements of vortices in superconductors, the study of energy-levels of large atoms (spectrum of large random matrices), theoretical physics models related to magnetism, but also more loosely connected to questions in biology, astrophysics, plasma physics, Bose-Einstein condensates, atomic clusters or hydrodynamics.

The first topic of the project is the statistical mechanics of Coulomb gases in an external potential and related models. This is motivated by random matrices, the fractional quantum Hall effect, and even approximation theory. One is interested in describing the macroscopic (mean-field) and microscopic arrangements of the many particles as their number N tends to infinity, and how they depend on temperature and the potential, and in particular whether some features are universal (i.e. independent of the potential) and whether there are phase transitions as the temperature varies. Recent works of the PI and collaborators have given insight into these questions with a proof that the fluctuations of the distribution of particles in a two-dimensional Coulomb gas converge to a Gaussian Free Field, and a Large Deviation Principle result which characterizes the limiting point processes at the microscopic scale as minimizing a certain rate function. With these results, one expects that the system should "crystallize" into a triangular lattice as the temperature tends to 0.The methods previously developed open the way to treating several important related questions: the case of higher-dimensional Coulomb gases, the case of more general interactions, the universality of the local statistics, the existence of a limiting point process, and the description of its long-range correlations. The second topic is that of vortices in the Ginzburg-Landau model of superconductivity, with pinning terms that introduce disorder and the final topic is to advance the analysis of mean-field dynamics for the simplest setting of many particles interacting via a repulsive singular interaction, a notoriously difficult question.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was concerned with large systems of points (or particles)  with Coulomb interaction (and some variants), which is one of the fundamental interactions of nature. Motivations come from statistical mechanics, condensed matter physics, random matrix theory (to study the spectra of large atoms), the fractional quantum Hall effect, and even approximation theory. 

The project studied such large systems from a mathematical point of view, focusing on deriving effective laws in three different settings: the minimization of the Coulomb repulsion for an infinite system in the presence of a uniform confinement force (a jellium, in physics), the study of effective dynamics for Coulomb interacting particles under Newton's law or the gradient flow of the interaction, and the study of Gibbs states with temperature in the frameowrk of statistical mechanics. 

In the first direction, progress was made with Mircea Petrache on the important crystallization question, showing that minimizers of Coulomb energies form lattices (or crystals) in dimensions 8 and 24, thanks to the recent breakthrough resolution of the Cohn-Kumar conjecture. The same holds in dimension 2 modulo the Cohn-Kumar conjecture. (2,8,24 are the only dimensions in which such a proof can apply).

In the second direction, an effective evolution equation for the density of particles flowing under Coulomb interaction (gradient flow or Hamiltonian flow) was rigorously derived for the first time (such results had previously been limited to more regular interactions). The Vlasov-Poisson equation, commonly used in plasma physics, was derived for the first time from Newton's law in work with Mitia Duerinckx, in the so-called "monokinetic case". 

In the third direction, progress was made with Scott Armstrong on the analysis of Coulomb gases at any temperature, showing "local laws" and "rigidity" results which characterize the microscopic behavior of the system and a rigid and uniform arrangement of the points despite the thermal effects. These results gave way to showing the existence of limiting microscopic arrangements of points (or point processes) whose existence is usually postulated by physicists, and to proving rigorous formulae for the free energy of the system, encoding its various physical properties. Finally, the Gaussian nature of the "fluctuations" in these systems was extended in dimension 2 to large regimes of temperature, and proven for the first time in dimension 3. 

Additional results of the project are the derivation of mean-field limits for vortices in superconductors with disorder, and the analysis of potential theory problems (such as the classical obstacle problem and equilibrium measure) motivated by Coulomb gases.
